urn:contentItem:6GJJ-T653-RV0R-92MB-00000-00WEEKLY ROUNDUP: URBAN REALM LIMITED NEWS THIS PAST WEEK AUG 21, 20252025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:32:44ZLexisNexisWEEKLY ROUNDUP: URBAN REALM LIMITED NEWS THIS PAST WEEK AUG 21, 2025

+ URBAN REALM LIMITED [10 Press Releases]

+ URBAN REALM LIMITED FORMER CHURCH TO MEET AFFORDABLE HOUSING DEMAND IN EDINBURGH

A 1950s church is to be redeveloped as affordable housing after permission was granted by City of Edinburgh Council.

The former St John Vianney's Roman Catholic Church at 40 Fernieside Gardens will be demolished by Cruden and replaced by 35 affordable homes designed by Hackland + Dore.

Fraser Lynes, managing director of Cruden Homes, said: "This development breathes new life into a redundant, brownfield site by placing sustainable communities and green infrastructure at its heart. It's another example of how thoughtful design can support Edinburgh's net-zero ambitions while meeting the critical need for affordable housing."

70% of the site will remain as open landscaped ground following development, half of which will be reserved for gardens.

Source: Company Website

+ URBAN REALM LIMITED TIME UP FOR GLASGOW OFFICE BLOCK AS STUDENT HOUSING GOES THROUGH THE ROOF

A defunct city centre office block is to give way to yet more student flats under detailed proposals submitted by Russ Drage Architects.

Following earlier consultations, the architects have returned with plans to replace the block with a 14-storey structure containing 259 student beds along with associated amenity areas and rooftop gardens.

Adjoining the recently completed Cadworks building, the development will address a prominent corner in the grid-iron CBD with a more exuberant crown inspired by the elaborate office building which occupied the site until the 1980s. Taking the form of a zinc mansard roof, the crown is topped by an outdoor roof terrace accessible from the main stair and lift core.

Source: Company Website

+ URBAN REALM LIMITED HUNDREDS OF HOMES TO DELIVER THE GOODS FOR GLASGOW

Glasgow's planning applications committee has awarded consent to a major residential project which promises to fill a brownfield void.

College Gardens is the latest iteration of long-held plans to open up the former College Street Goods Yard through the delivery of 713 build-to-rent homes, as well as 999 student beds.

Nick Ecob, director at Stallan-Brand commented: "The project will have a transformative impact on the eastern edge of the city centre, delivering new homes, green spaces and improved connectivity whilst making a positive contribution to wider local economy."

Heralded as a major step towards repopulating the city centre, the mammoth project by Galliard Apsley Partnership will open up public access with new green spaces overseen by LDA Design. This will see new pedestrian and cycle routes threaded through the largely car-free development connecting a series of new open spaces.

Awarding consent, the committee wrote: "Whilst a small part of the site is located on the boundary of the Conservation Area, it is not considered that the proposals will impact the special character or setting of this and will provide a positive contribution to the surrounding townscape through the redevelopment of a derelict site.

Source: Company Website

+ URBAN REALM LIMITED DISHOOM OFFERS GLASGOW DINERS A TASTE OF BOMBAY

A popular Indian restaurant has opened its first Glasgow premises with the opening of a new cafe in the city's former Stock Market.

Dishoom will open its doors on 29 August, serving meals within a mid-century Bombay-inspired interior designed by Macaulay Sinclair.

The restaurant occupies 6,720sq/ft of the historic building, featuring a bespoke hardwood bar lined by aged brass and a marble floor. Diners will also be greeted by a feature double-sided clock integrated within a glazed screen.

Vintage light fittings sourced from Bombay (now Mumbai) add authenticity with geometric terrazzo, vintage parquet, polished plaster walls and concrete ceilings completing the look.

Source: Company Website

+ URBAN REALM LIMITED PAISLEY HARBOUR BRIDGE TO IMPROVE REGIONAL CONNECTIVITY

Renfrewshire Council is investing £59m in new road and river routes, including a Paisley Harbour Bridge, to boost connectivity across the region.

The transport plan will link the town centre to Glasgow Airport via the Advanced Manufacturing Innovation District Scotland along a 1.7km route alongside the White Cart River.

A new network of roads, cycling and walking links will reduce journey times and open up new opportunities for travel with additional feeder routes including a new connection to Renfrew Road serving the proposed Paisley Grammar. A former railway underpass beneath this route will be pressed back into service to provide safe access to the Gallowhill Link. under the plans.

Council Leader Iain Nicolson said: "This project will not only provide infrastructure to better connect communities to education and employment opportunities, but it will also significantly improve the offer to organisations looking to locate here with enhanced access to the airport and the fourth-busiest train station in Scotland."

Source: Company Website

+ URBAN REALM LIMITED GRANTON STATION PLATFORMS TO WELCOME FIRST NEW ARRIVALS IN A CENTURY

Disused platforms at the former Granton Station in Edinburgh, which has recently been transformed into a hub for creatives, are to be landscaped as part of improvement works to the adjacent Station Square.

Source: Company Website

+ URBAN REALM LIMITED JEDBURGH PILOT ESTABLISHES GARAGE-TO-HOMES TEMPLATE

A garages-to-homes initiative in the Scottish Borders is transforming disused spaces into desperately needed new housing, the first initiative of its kind in Scotland.

Scottish Borders Housing Association has spearheaded the project, inviting housing providers from across the country to the launch event at Butler Court, where four accessible and energy-efficient bungalows were unveiled.

The project architect is Russell Edwards of Edwards Architecture, working with garage-to-home regeneration specialist HUSK, which provides each home with air source heat pumps, PV solar panels, a fire suppression system, and A-rated EPCs.

Russell Edwards, managing director of HUSK, commented: "The Garages to Homes model allows us to reuse existing structures in a sustainable way, providing high-quality living spaces while reducing waste and construction time."

Source: Company Website

+ URBAN REALM LIMITED HUNDREDS OF HOMES BREATHE LIFE INTO GLASGOW'S INNER CITY

The first phase of a significant new residential development in the heart of Glasgow's east end has completed, helping to repopulate inner city brownfield land.

Wheatley Homes with Hypostyle and McTaggart Construction have delivered the first 90 homes of the broader 264-home Calton Village development off the Gallowgate, comprising a mix of flats and houses for social and mid-market rent.

Powered by the largest district heating network in the city, the highly insulated homes draw energy for heating and water from a central hub.

Wheatley Group director of development and regeneration, Lindsay Lauder, said: "Bringing this site back to life is a major investment in the area, delivering high-quality, energy-efficient homes in a great location close to the city centre.

Source: Company Website

+ URBAN REALM LIMITEDDISUSED VIADUCT TO CONNECT CARMYLE AND WESTBURN AGAIN

A disused railway line spanning the River Clyde could become an active travel route connecting Carmyle and Westburn, according to a new planning application.

Sustrans has asked Amey Consulting to help bring the viaduct back into use as a walking and cycling corridor, including a replacement superstructure and amphitheatre-style social spaces.

Dating from the 1890s and fully decommissioned in 1983 the 130m crossing sits on sandstone piers and is considered dangerous in its present condition. Reclaimed steel and stone will be repurposed as benches, planters and signage with overgrowth cut back on both banks to open up river views.

Source: Company Website

+ URBAN REALM LIMITED EBBING OFFICE DEMAND PROMPTS STUDENT SHIFT IN GLASGOW'S OFFICE CORE

A Glasgow office block is to be transformed beyond recognition to help accommodate the city's burgeoning student population.

Occupancy at 33 Bothwell Street has declined to 50% as tenants shift to hybrid working and more modern accommodation, prompting Cordatus Real Estate and 3DReid Architects to pursue a change of use application.

A rooftop extension will build up the corner profile of the existing six-storey 1970s building with two additional floors and a feature lantern mirroring a domed tower opposite, allowing the building to accommodate 99 rooms. Building upon the current ashlar stone facade the extension will feature bronze metal cladding with perforated details extending the horizontal banding of the floors below.

Source: Company Website

urn:contentItem:6GJK-8Y03-S3G2-7346-00000-00How AECOM Has Fared Since Its Recent Analyst Ratings Changes - what Analysts are saying2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:32:44ZLexisNexisHow AECOM Has Fared Since Its Recent Analyst Ratings Changes - what Analysts are saying

NYSE STOCK REPORT

AECOM (NYSE:ACM), the NYSE's 8th largest Construction company by market cap, is up 15% Year to Date. There have been changes in analyst ratings and target prices in 2025 - some forward-looking and others that have been after price movements. Below are the recent analyst ratings changes and the change in company stock price since.

Rating DateAnalyst FirmRatingTarget PriceReturn Since Change (%)12 Aug, 2025BarclaysOverweight to Overweight120 to 1300.606 Aug, 2025KeyCorpOverweight to Overweight129 to 1312.306 Aug, 2025UBS GroupBuy to Buy126 to 1392.305 Aug, 2025Bank of AmericaBuy to Buy112 to 1242.216 Jul, 2025KeyCorpOverweight to Overweight120 to 1297.407 May, 2025CitigroupBuy to Buy116 to 12220.107 May, 2025Royal Bank of CanadaOutperform to Outperform123 to 12620.106 May, 2025Robert W. BairdOutperform to Outperform108 to 11818.425 Apr, 2025CitigroupBuy to Buy127 to 11625.216 Apr, 2025KeyCorpOverweight to Overweight121 to 10930.7

AECOM Snapshot

AECOM Latest Earnings Highlights

Highlights of the Latest Earnings Report Q2 Fiscal 2025

AECOM posted adjusted earnings per share (EPS) of $1.25, exceeding forecasts by 8.7% and marking a 20% increase compared to the previous year.

Revenues experienced a decline year-over-year, though net service revenues (NSR) rose by 1%, reaching $742 million, supported by strong performance in the United Kingdom and Hong Kong markets.

Operating cash flow significantly increased by 102% to $191 million, while adjusted free cash flow surged by 141% to $178 million.

The company's total backlog climbed to $17.78 billion, compared to $17.38 billion during the same period last year, securing strong future revenue opportunities.

Guidance for fiscal 2025 was raised, with adjusted EPS projected between $5.10 and $5.20 and adjusted EBITDA between $1.180 and $1.210 billion, alongside NSR growth expectations of 5-8%.

Adjusted EBITDA margins are anticipated to improve by 30 basis points, ranging from 16.1% to 16.3%, with over 100% conversion from adjusted net income to free cash flow expected.

International revenues dropped by 3% to $875 million; however, operational improvements contributed to a margin expansion of 10 basis points, reaching 11.1%.

Analyst Commentary

Strong Margin Expansion and Operational Efficiency

Observers highlight AECOM's ongoing progress towards achieving its goal of a 17%-plus margin. This success is attributed to a strategic focus on high-margin markets and efficient project execution processes that enhance profitability.

Operational efficiency, supported by disciplined cost management, has enabled reinvestment into high-return initiatives, further strengthening long-term competitiveness.

Robust Cash Flow and Capital Allocation

Exceptional free cash flow growth of 141% underscores the company's healthy financial position. This robust cash flow supports disciplined strategies, including consistent share repurchases and annual dividend growth commitments exceeding 20%.

Resilient Backlog and Pipeline Growth

AECOM's record-breaking backlog of $17.78 billion and a book-to-burn ratio of 1.2x in its design business signify continued demand. The infrastructure and environmental sectors are noted as drivers propelling global growth opportunities.

urn:contentItem:6FXP-4XS3-SF1F-W4XG-00000-00Bush food in council greening strategy2025-05-31T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:32:43ZLexisNexisNEWS4Bush food in council greening strategySean Ford

'(It) could bring added depth and meaning to public spaces.'

Going into town for a feed could take on a whole new meaning when a North-West council's greening strategy takes effect.

Bush foods for the public could join the attractions of Smithton and Stanley after the Circular Head Council adopts a proposed greening strategy.

"Community gardens, edible verges and shared orchards promote food security and encourage connection," council staff said in the draft strategy.

"Involving Aboriginal knowledge and seasonal bush food planting could bring added depth and meaning to public spaces.

"We can recognise our shared history and culture by drawing on local Aboriginal knowledge to plant natives and bush foods and create yarning circles."

Bush food expert and author Rees Campbell was impressed by the council's thinking.

"A native edible food trail is a fantastic idea," Wynyard-based Ms Campbell said.

"There's quite a few where you can nibble at the whole plant. Obviously, you'd have to choose your plants, but it could be done quite easily with quite a range of plants."

She believed bush food could become a visitor attraction for Smithton and Stanley, especially if it had cultural interpretation signage.

The council's draft said: "In partnership with traditional custodians, greening efforts can also support caring for country, recognising that land, waters, plants, animals and people are deeply interconnected."

"Green spaces can honour Aboriginal seasonal knowledge, provide opportunities for cultural practices like storytelling and gathering and act as places of healing and learning for the whole community.

"Through thoughtful planting and design, we can celebrate both the ancient and evolving relationship between people and place."

The draft said bush foods, herbs and fruiting plants had cultural and practical value.

The council said the strategy would provide a "guiding framework" for including "green infrastructure", such as trees and landscaping, in the future planning, design and maintenance of public spaces in the two towns.

Actions listed in the draft included:

Trialling low-maintenance demonstration gardens in the towns;

planting trees along key walking routes;

promoting verge planting in residential streets through nature strip guidelines;

integrating greening with seating, shelters and accessible pathways;

trialling pop-up gardens, seasonal planter boxes and parklets in high-use areas;

integrating public art, such as sculptural planters and storytelling trails, into greening efforts;

proritising the planting of native species wherever possible

urn:contentItem:6GJC-9SG3-S0CP-J523-00000-00AECOM's Earnings Growth Outperforms Stantec - what Analysts are saying2025-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:32:43ZLexisNexisAECOM's Earnings Growth Outperforms Stantec - what Analysts are saying

NYSE STOCK REPORT

AECOM's growth in EPS (earnings per share) has been 36% annualized over 3 years. Over the same time period its stock price has gone up 60.3% or 0% annualized.

In comparison, Stantec's growth in EPS (earnings per share) has been 20.8% annualized over 3 years. Over the same time period its stock price has gone up 129.5% or 29.7% annualized.

AECOM's last trading price was $119.90 which implies a Price to Earnings multiple of 40.4. With an EPS growth rate of 36 that implies a PEG ratio (price/earnings to growth) of 1.12 when using the EPS growth rate of the past 3 years (investors prefer using a 3-year expected growth rate instead but each investor will have a different perspective on future growth).

Stantec's last trading price was CAD147.16 which implies a Price to Earnings multiple of 43.7. With an EPS growth rate of 20.8 that implies a PEG ratio (price/earnings to growth) of 2.1 when using the EPS growth rate of the past 3 years (investors prefer using a 3-year expected growth rate instead but each investor will have a different perspective on future growth).

AECOM Snapshot

AECOM Latest Earnings Highlights

Highlights of the Latest Earnings Report Q2 Fiscal 2025

AECOM posted adjusted earnings per share (EPS) of $1.25, exceeding forecasts by 8.7% and marking a 20% increase compared to the previous year.

Revenues experienced a decline year-over-year, though net service revenues (NSR) rose by 1%, reaching $742 million, supported by strong performance in the United Kingdom and Hong Kong markets.

Operating cash flow significantly increased by 102% to $191 million, while adjusted free cash flow surged by 141% to $178 million.

The company's total backlog climbed to $17.78 billion, compared to $17.38 billion during the same period last year, securing strong future revenue opportunities.

Guidance for fiscal 2025 was raised, with adjusted EPS projected between $5.10 and $5.20 and adjusted EBITDA between $1.180 and $1.210 billion, alongside NSR growth expectations of 5-8%.

Adjusted EBITDA margins are anticipated to improve by 30 basis points, ranging from 16.1% to 16.3%, with over 100% conversion from adjusted net income to free cash flow expected.

International revenues dropped by 3% to $875 million; however, operational improvements contributed to a margin expansion of 10 basis points, reaching 11.1%.

Analyst Commentary

Strong Margin Expansion and Operational Efficiency

Observers highlight AECOM's ongoing progress towards achieving its goal of a 17%-plus margin. This success is attributed to a strategic focus on high-margin markets and efficient project execution processes that enhance profitability.

Operational efficiency, supported by disciplined cost management, has enabled reinvestment into high-return initiatives, further strengthening long-term competitiveness.

Robust Cash Flow and Capital Allocation

Exceptional free cash flow growth of 141% underscores the company's healthy financial position. This robust cash flow supports disciplined strategies, including consistent share repurchases and annual dividend growth commitments exceeding 20%.

Resilient Backlog and Pipeline Growth

Optimism for Long-Term Prospects

urn:contentItem:6GFS-65W3-RSCM-04V7-00000-00A&O SHEARMAN - SECTOR INSIGHT FROM PEERS2025-08-09T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:32:44ZLexisNexisSTOCKA&O SHEARMAN - SECTOR INSIGHT FROM PEERS

DASHBOARD: A&O SHEARMAN

PermID4296376346Websitehttps://www.aoshearman.com/enIndustryLegal Services

ACTIVITIES:

A&O Shearman was formed in 2024 via the merger of two historic firms, Allen & Overy and Shearman & Sterling. A firm built to achieve unparalleled outcomes With nearly 4,000 lawyers globally, we are equally fluent in English law, U.S. law and the laws of the world's most dynamic markets.

+ A&O SHEARMAN [3 Press Releases]

+ A&O SHEARMAN MITIGATING THIRD-PARTY PROVIDER CYBERSECURITY RISKS: NAVIGATING THE AUSTRALIAN LEGAL FRAMEWORK

Cybersecurity breaches originating from third-party providers (TPPs) are an escalating concern for Australian businesses. As supply chain risks grow, there is a mounting public expectation that the entity that commissioned the collection of personal information remains accountable for its protection, even when such personal information is handled and managed by a TPP.

Despite recent political commentary in Australia regarding the tightening of privacy laws, there is no current legal requirement for businesses to store data, including any personal information, in-house. As a result, organizations are increasingly relying on TPPs to manage their data as TPPs can be highly cost-effective and often provide superior specialist services. To maximize the benefit of using TPPs, robust legal risk management is essential.

Source: Company Website

+ A&O SHEARMAN UK PENSIONS: WHAT'S NEW THIS WEEKAUGUST 4, 2025

TPR blog post on managing systemic risks The latest blog post from the Pensions Regulator (TPR) highlights the importance of managing systemic risks, including climate change, nature loss and broader ESG factors, as "a core part" of effective scheme governance and trustees' fiduciary responsibilities. TPR encourages schemes to use the Taskforce on Nature-related Financial Disclosures (TNFD) resources to inform their thinking. The blog post includes questions trustees should ask themselves to help assess how well equipped they are in this area. TPR urges trustees to engage with the recent consultation on mandating transition plans and asks for input for its transition planning industry group.

Read the blog post.

Data (Use and Access) Act: commencement regulations Regulations have been made bringing certain parts of the Data (Use and Access) Act 2025 into force with effect from August 20, 2025. Provisions potentially relevant to pension schemes include changes relating to processing of special categories of data and modifications to court procedures dealing with data subject access requests. Regulations setting out further details and bringing other parts of the act into force are awaited.

Read the Data (Use and Access) Act 2025 (Commencement No. 1) Regulations 2025.

Source: Company Website

+ A&O SHEARMAN COMMISSION NOT IMPOSSIBLE: NO BRIBERY OR FIDUCIARY BREACH IN CAR FINANCE COMMISSION CASE

In a significant decision for the car finance industry, the UK Supreme Court has decided that lenders who financed car loans were not liable to their customers for bribery for failing to obtain their informed consent to commission payments made by the lenders to the dealers arranging the finance.

The court determined that, for the tort of bribery to be committed, the recipient of the bribe must be a fiduciary, and the dealers did not owe a fiduciary duty to their customers. For the same reason, the lenders had not dishonestly assisted in a breach of fiduciary duty by the dealers.

In relation to one customer, however, liability did arise on the basis there was an unfair relationship between the customer and lender for the purposes of the Consumer Credit Act 1974.

The decision largely overturns the Court of Appeal's controversial judgment from last autumn which held that lenders financing car loans could be liable in such cases.

Source: Company Website

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

+ WHITE & CASE LLP [6 Press Releases]

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES WHITEFIBER ON UPSIZED IPO

Global law firm White & Case LLP has advised leading artificial intelligence infrastructure solutions provider, WhiteFiber, Inc., on its upsized initial public offering of 9.375 million ordinary shares at a price of US$17.00 per share, including granting the underwriters a 30-day option to purchase up to an additional 1,406,250 ordinary shares at the initial public offering price. WhiteFiber is listed on the Nasdaq Capital Market under the symbol WYFI. The offering closed on August 8, 2025.

WhiteFiber owns high-performance computing data centers and provides cloud services to customers. Its vertically integrated model combines specialized colocation, hosting and cloud services engineered to maximize performance, efficiency and margin for generative AI workloads.

The White & Case team was led by Capital Markets partner Laura Katherine Mann (Houston), and included M&A partners Prat Vallabhaneni, Erica Hogan and Nicholas Luciano (all in New York); Tax partner Neil Clausen (Houston); and Capital Markets associates Melissa Curvino (New York), Bryson Manning, Chanel Holmes, Brandon Wong and Daniel Quesenberry (all in Houston).

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES ON LANDMARK ACWA POWER COMPANY RIGHTS ISSUE

Global law firm White & Case LLP has advised the underwriters on ACWA Power Company's SAR 7.125 billion rights issue - one of the largest capital raises in the history of the Saudi capital market.

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE SECURES DISMISSAL OF DEUTSCHE BAHN'S STUTTGART 21 COST OVERRUN LAWSUIT FOR STATE OF BADEN-W RTTEMBERG

Global law firm White & Case LLP has secured a victory for the State of Baden-Wurttemberg in the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg, which rejected Deutsche Bahn's request to appeal a 2024 judgment by the Stuttgart Administrative Court related to the financing of the Stuttgart 21 project.

"At no point did the State of Baden-Wurttemberg assume any obligation to cover the cost overruns of the Stuttgart 21 project," said White & Case partner Henning Berger, who led the team which achieved the dismissals before both the Stuttgart Administrative Court and the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg. "The state only made specific financial contributions under public subsidy law, as clearly and unambiguously defined in the financing agreement. The Administrative Court of Appeal has now confirmed this in its decision."

The Stuttgart Administrative Court had dismissed Deutsche Bahn's claim for approximately EUR7 billion in additional project costs against the State of Baden-Wurttemberg and other defendants relating to the financing of the Stuttgart 21 project. The decision of the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg, which is final and cannot be appealed, establishes the Stuttgart Administrative Court's ruling as legally binding and definitively establishes that the State of Baden-Wurttemberg is not responsible for covering the significant cost overruns of the Stuttgart 21 project. Neither the so-called 'negotiation clause' in the Stuttgart 21 financing agreement, nor any other contractual or statutory basis, creates an obligation for the state to bear these additional costs in whole or in part

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE PARTNER ON USING LEGAL KNOWLEDGE AS A SPRINGBOARD

In a Q&A with International Financial Law Review as part of its "Five minutes with" series, White & Case partner Jessica Chen discussed her practice and career.

When providing an overview of her work, Jessica explained: "I help companies raise capital, mainly using their equity, in order to fund initiatives that help the company grow." She noted that she spends much of her days working with clients and colleagues across Europe and Asia, also emphasizing the support she receives from the "brilliant associates" she works alongside.

"The most exciting aspect is that each day is different, and I never know what new issues will come my way," Jessica said, adding that the Firm is "at the forefront of structuring new ways of doing things and figuring out how it works."

While Jessica noted the importance of understanding the rules as a lawyer, she argues that "a truly great lawyer then uses that knowledge as a springboard."

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES SUMMIT PARTNERS ON INVESTMENT IN DREAMPATH DIAGNOSTICS

Global law firm White & Case LLP has advised leading growth-focused investment firm Summit Partners on its investment in Dreampath Diagnostics.

The investment will support the company's plans to accelerate global growth, scale operations and expand its commercial reach and product portfolio. As part of the transaction, two members of the Summit Partners team will join the Dreampath DiagnosticsBoard of Directors.

Dreampath Diagnostics is a global leader in digital sample management systems for anatomical pathology laboratories.

The White & Case team which advised on the transaction was led by partner Guillaume Vitrich (Paris) and included partners Alexandre Jaurett, Clara Hainsdorf, Orion Berg, Quirec de Kersauson, Brice Engel, Kami Haeri (all Paris), Hope Anderson (Los Angeles), David Bond, Farhad Jalinous (both Washington, DC), Jaye Kasper, Bethany Hills, Tal Marnin, Sasha Belinkie, Scott Fryman (all New York), Carlos Daroca (Madrid) and Alan Bao (Beijing), counsel Amanda Woodall (Houston), Katrin Helle (Berlin), Annie Anderson, Heidi Schmid (both New York) and Chris Thomas (London) and associates Nicolas Alfonsi, Marco Hladik, Matthieu Shamloo, Sarah Kouchad, Hovig Cancioglu, Olga Kosno, Louis Roussier, Pauline Abbouche, Gregoire Baudry, Clement Bellaclas, Mathilde Bernier, Dylan Deligny (all Paris), Benedict Tansey, Kyle Spencer, Alec Buchanan, Amanda Kingsley, Sam Ahmad (all London), Edward Ernst (New York), Allison Kepkay, Timothy Sensenig (both Washington, DC), Lucee Laursen (Chicago), Zixie Zhu (Beijing), Qianru Hong (Shanghai) and Joao Lacerda (London & Brussels).

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES FOTOWATIO RENEWABLE VENTURES (FRV) AUSTRALIA ON DEVELOPMENT AND FINANCING OF GNARWARRE BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM

Global law firm White & Case LLP has advised Fotowatio Renewable Ventures (FRV) Australia on the development and financing of the 250 MW/500 MWh Gnarwarre battery energy storage system (BESS), near Geelong in the state of Victoria.

"FRVAustralia successfully leveraged its existing portfolio financing facility to finance the construction of the Gnarwarre BESS," said White & Case partner Candice Ota, who co-led the Firm's deal team. "Portfolio financing facilities can provide developers with greater flexibility to fund their development pipeline."

The stand-alone BESS project includes grid forming inverters and will assist the national electrical network to compensate for times of peak demand and energy oversupply.

The Gnarwarre BESS is FRVAustralia's largest battery to date and was financed under its A$1.2 billion portfolio financing facility, which was established in July 2024. The loan facility was provided by a syndicate of five financial institutions: Westpac Banking Corporation, United Overseas Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo, KfW IPEX-Bank and Export Development Canada. The project's funding also includes grant funding from the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA), which awarded a A$15 million grant under its Large Scale Battery Storage Funding Round.

+ CAHILL SECURES VICTORY FOR GLOBAL SOCIAL MEDIA COMPANY, OVERTURNING CALIFORNIA'S ANTI-DEEPFAKE LAW

Cahill prevailed in a precedent-setting victory for a leading social media platform in the Eastern District of California, where the court struck down a California law that would have forced covered social media platforms to remove or label certain political speech about elections that the State deems false or misleading.

Source: Company Website

+ CAHILL GORDON & REINDEL LLP: CAHILL HONORED WITH SANCTUARY FOR FAMILIES' 2025 ABOVE & BEYOND PRO BONO ACHIEVEMENT AWARD

Cahill has been named a recipient of Sanctuary For Families' 2025 Above & Beyond Pro Bono Achievement Award.

Following years of continual work, a Cahill pro bono team led by partner Joel Kurtzberg and including associates Joe Adams, Lisa Cole, Brigid O'Keefe, Chana Tauber, and Jessica Urgo will receive the Above & Beyond award from Sanctuary For Families in recognition of their representation of a woman seeking custody of her nephew after the sudden death of child's mother and obtaining an order of protection against the child's father, in addition to Cahill's representation in a related Hague Convention case.

When Cahill joined the matter, the Hague court had already issued orders on two separate occasions requiring the child to go back to his father in Italy, despite crediting allegations of abuse. Cahill worked together with another law firm in the Hague case and prevailed in persuading the Hague judge to reverse her prior rulings and keep the child in New York while custody was being litigated because of the grave risk of harm to the child if he were returned to the father in Italy. Cahill also was successful in negotiating a settlement in a Family Court case that provided full legal and physical custody for our client, a 2-year order of protection, and supervised virtual visitation for the father.

DASHBOARD: WHITE & CASE LLP

PermID4296278714Websitehttp://www.whitecase.com/IndustryLaw PracticeAddress75 State Street Boston, Massachusetts 02109-1814 United States

ACTIVITIES:

White & Case LLP, founded in 1901, is a global law firm headquartered in New York City. With over 2,600 lawyers across 44 offices, it serves clients in finance, energy, and technology, specializing in M&A, project finance, and international arbitration. Generating over $2.5 billion annually, White & Case advised on major 2024 deals, including cross-border energy transactions. Its culture fosters collaboration, diversity, and pro bono work, earning high workplace rankings. Competing with Latham & Watkins, White & Case stands out for its global reach and expertise in emerging markets. Recent initiatives include expanding ESG and digital asset practices, aligning with regulatory and tech trends.

+ WHITE & CASE LLP [6 Press Releases]

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES ON LANDMARK ACWA POWER COMPANY RIGHTS ISSUE

Global law firmWhite & Case LLP has advised the underwriters on ACWA Power Company's SAR 7.125 billion rights issue - one of the largest capital raises in the history of the Saudi capital market.

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES WHITEFIBER ON UPSIZED IPO

Global law firmWhite & Case LLP has advised leading artificial intelligence infrastructure solutions provider, WhiteFiber, Inc., on its upsized initial public offering of 9.375 million ordinary shares at a price of US$17.00 per share, including granting the underwriters a 30-day option to purchase up to an additional 1,406,250 ordinary shares at the initial public offering price. WhiteFiber is listed on the Nasdaq Capital Market under the symbol WYFI. The offering closed on August 8, 2025.

WhiteFiber owns high-performance computing data centers and provides cloud services to customers. Its vertically integrated model combines specialized colocation, hosting and cloud services engineered to maximize performance, efficiency and margin for generative AI workloads.

The White & Case team was led by Capital Markets partner Laura Katherine Mann (Houston), and included M&A partners Prat Vallabhaneni, Erica Hogan and Nicholas Luciano (all in New York); Tax partner Neil Clausen (Houston); and Capital Markets associates Melissa Curvino (New York), Bryson Manning, Chanel Holmes, Brandon Wong and Daniel Quesenberry (all in Houston).

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE PARTNER ON USING LEGAL KNOWLEDGE AS A SPRINGBOARD

In a Q&A with International Financial Law Review as part of its "Five minutes with" series, White & Case partner Jessica Chen discussed her practice and career.

When providing an overview of her work, Jessica explained: "I help companies raise capital, mainly using their equity, in order to fund initiatives that help the company grow." She noted that she spends much of her days working with clients and colleagues across Europe and Asia, also emphasizing the support she receives from the "brilliant associates" she works alongside.

"The most exciting aspect is that each day is different, and I never know what new issues will come my way," Jessica said, adding that the Firm is "at the forefront of structuring new ways of doing things and figuring out how it works."

While Jessica noted the importance of understanding the rules as a lawyer, she argues that "a truly great lawyer then uses that knowledge as a springboard."

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES FOTOWATIO RENEWABLE VENTURES (FRV) AUSTRALIA ON DEVELOPMENT AND FINANCING OF GNARWARRE BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM

Global law firmWhite & Case LLP has advised Fotowatio Renewable Ventures (FRV) Australia on the development and financing of the 250 MW/500 MWh Gnarwarre battery energy storage system (BESS), near Geelong in the state of Victoria.

"FRVAustralia successfully leveraged its existing portfolio financing facility to finance the construction of the Gnarwarre BESS," said White & Case partner Candice Ota, who co-led the Firm's deal team. "Portfolio financing facilities can provide developers with greater flexibility to fund their development pipeline."

The stand-alone BESS project includes grid forming inverters and will assist the national electrical network to compensate for times of peak demand and energy oversupply.

The Gnarwarre BESS is FRVAustralia's largest battery to date and was financed under its A$1.2 billion portfolio financing facility, which was established in July 2024. The loan facility was provided by a syndicate of five financial institutions: Westpac Banking Corporation, United Overseas Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo, KfW IPEX-Bank and Export Development Canada. The project's funding also includes grant funding from the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA), which awarded a A$15 million grant under its Large Scale Battery Storage Funding Round.

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE SECURES DISMISSAL OF DEUTSCHE BAHN'S STUTTGART 21 COST OVERRUN LAWSUIT FOR STATE OF BADEN-W RTTEMBERG

Global law firmWhite & Case LLP has secured a victory for the State of Baden-Wurttemberg in the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg, which rejected Deutsche Bahn's request to appeal a 2024 judgment by the Stuttgart Administrative Court related to the financing of the Stuttgart 21 project.

"At no point did the State of Baden-Wurttemberg assume any obligation to cover the cost overruns of the Stuttgart 21 project," said White & Case partner Henning Berger, who led the team which achieved the dismissals before both the Stuttgart Administrative Court and the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg. "The state only made specific financial contributions under public subsidy law, as clearly and unambiguously defined in the financing agreement. The Administrative Court of Appeal has now confirmed this in its decision."

The Stuttgart Administrative Court had dismissed Deutsche Bahn's claim for approximately EUR7 billion in additional project costs against the State of Baden-Wurttemberg and other defendants relating to the financing of the Stuttgart 21 project. The decision of the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg, which is final and cannot be appealed, establishes the Stuttgart Administrative Court's ruling as legally binding and definitively establishes that the State of Baden-Wurttemberg is not responsible for covering the significant cost overruns of the Stuttgart 21 project. Neither the so-called 'negotiation clause' in the Stuttgart 21 financing agreement, nor any other contractual or statutory basis, creates an obligation for the state to bear these additional costs in whole or in part

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES SUMMIT PARTNERS ON INVESTMENT IN DREAMPATH DIAGNOSTICS

Global law firmWhite & Case LLP has advised leading growth-focused investment firm Summit Partners on its investment in Dreampath Diagnostics.

The investment will support the company's plans to accelerate global growth, scale operations and expand its commercial reach and product portfolio. As part of the transaction, two members of the Summit Partners team will join the Dreampath DiagnosticsBoard of Directors.

Dreampath Diagnostics is a global leader in digital sample management systems for anatomical pathology laboratories.

The White & Case team which advised on the transaction was led by partner Guillaume Vitrich (Paris) and included partners Alexandre Jaurett, Clara Hainsdorf, Orion Berg, Quirec de Kersauson, Brice Engel, Kami Haeri (all Paris), Hope Anderson (Los Angeles), David Bond, Farhad Jalinous (both Washington, DC), Jaye Kasper, Bethany Hills, Tal Marnin, Sasha Belinkie, Scott Fryman (all New York), Carlos Daroca (Madrid) and Alan Bao (Beijing), counsel Amanda Woodall (Houston), Katrin Helle (Berlin), Annie Anderson, Heidi Schmid (both New York) and Chris Thomas (London) and associates Nicolas Alfonsi, Marco Hladik, Matthieu Shamloo, Sarah Kouchad, Hovig Cancioglu, Olga Kosno, Louis Roussier, Pauline Abbouche, Gregoire Baudry, Clement Bellaclas, Mathilde Bernier, Dylan Deligny (all Paris), Benedict Tansey, Kyle Spencer, Alec Buchanan, Amanda Kingsley, Sam Ahmad (all London), Edward Ernst (New York), Allison Kepkay, Timothy Sensenig (both Washington, DC), Lucee Laursen (Chicago), Zixie Zhu (Beijing), Qianru Hong (Shanghai) and Joao Lacerda (London & Brussels).

+ BAKER MCKENZIE [3 Press Releases]

+ BAKER MCKENZIE PUBLISHES ANNUAL SUSTAINABILITY REPORT 2025

Leading global law firm Baker McKenzie has published its Annual Sustainability Report 2025, which provides an overview of the progress the Firm made in 2024 to advance its eight prioritized Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and its broader sustainability strategy.

The report highlights Baker McKenzie's 2024 actions across key sustainability areas - spanning inclusion, diversity and equity, environmental impact, governance and the rule of law, and also reaffirms the Firm's commitment as a longstanding active participant of the UN Global Compact, upholding its Ten Principles on human rights, labor, the environment, and anti-corruption - and more broadly, its dedication to responsible business practices.

2024 was also the year of Baker McKenzie's 75th anniversary, and the Firm celebrated this milestone by demonstrating its deep commitment to local communities through a "Make a Difference Month" in July 2024.

+ BAKER MCKENZIE FIBRA NEXT ISSUES APPROXIMATELY USD 450 MILLION OF REAL ESTATE TRUST CERTIFICATES IN INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING

+ A&O SHEARMAN [3 Press Releases]

+ A&O SHEARMAN MITIGATING THIRD-PARTY PROVIDER CYBERSECURITY RISKS: NAVIGATING THE AUSTRALIAN LEGAL FRAMEWORK

Cybersecurity breaches originating from third-party providers (TPPs) are an escalating concern for Australian businesses. As supply chain risks grow, there is a mounting public expectation that the entity that commissioned the collection of personal information remains accountable for its protection, even when such personal information is handled and managed by a TPP.

Despite recent political commentary in Australia regarding the tightening of privacy laws, there is no current legal requirement for businesses to store data, including any personal information, in-house. As a result, organizations are increasingly relying on TPPs to manage their data as TPPs can be highly cost-effective and often provide superior specialist services. To maximize the benefit of using TPPs, robust legal risk management is essential.

Source: Company Website

+ A&O SHEARMAN UK PENSIONS: WHAT'S NEW THIS WEEKAUGUST 4, 2025

TPR blog post on managing systemic risks The latest blog post from the Pensions Regulator (TPR) highlights the importance of managing systemic risks, including climate change, nature loss and broader ESG factors, as "a core part" of effective scheme governance and trustees' fiduciary responsibilities. TPR encourages schemes to use the Taskforce on Nature-related Financial Disclosures (TNFD) resources to inform their thinking. The blog post includes questions trustees should ask themselves to help assess how well equipped they are in this area. TPR urges trustees to engage with the recent consultation on mandating transition plans and asks for input for its transition planning industry group.

Read the blog post.

Data (Use and Access) Act: commencement regulations Regulations have been made bringing certain parts of the Data (Use and Access) Act 2025 into force with effect from August 20, 2025. Provisions potentially relevant to pension schemes include changes relating to processing of special categories of data and modifications to court procedures dealing with data subject access requests. Regulations setting out further details and bringing other parts of the act into force are awaited.

Read the Data (Use and Access) Act 2025 (Commencement No. 1) Regulations 2025.

Source: Company Website

+ A&O SHEARMAN COMMISSION NOT IMPOSSIBLE: NO BRIBERY OR FIDUCIARY BREACH IN CAR FINANCE COMMISSION CASE

In a significant decision for the car finance industry, the UK Supreme Court has decided that lenders who financed car loans were not liable to their customers for bribery for failing to obtain their informed consent to commission payments made by the lenders to the dealers arranging the finance.

The court determined that, for the tort of bribery to be committed, the recipient of the bribe must be a fiduciary, and the dealers did not owe a fiduciary duty to their customers. For the same reason, the lenders had not dishonestly assisted in a breach of fiduciary duty by the dealers.

In relation to one customer, however, liability did arise on the basis there was an unfair relationship between the customer and lender for the purposes of the Consumer Credit Act 1974.

The decision largely overturns the Court of Appeal's controversial judgment from last autumn which held that lenders financing car loans could be liable in such cases.

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES WHITEFIBER ON UPSIZED IPO

Global law firm White & Case LLP has advised leading artificial intelligence infrastructure solutions provider, WhiteFiber, Inc., on its upsized initial public offering of 9.375 million ordinary shares at a price of US$17.00 per share, including granting the underwriters a 30-day option to purchase up to an additional 1,406,250 ordinary shares at the initial public offering price. + WHITE & CASE SECURES DISMISSAL OF DEUTSCHE BAHN'S STUTTGART 21 COST OVERRUN LAWSUIT FOR STATE OF BADEN-W RTTEMBERG

Global law firm White & Case LLP has secured a victory for the State of Baden-Wurttemberg in the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg, which rejected Deutsche Bahn's request to appeal a 2024 judgment by the Stuttgart Administrative Court related to the financing of the Stuttgart 21 project.

"At no point did the State of Baden-Wurttemberg assume any obligation to cover the cost overruns of the Stuttgart 21 project," said White & Case partner Henning Berger, who led the team which achieved the dismissals before both the Stuttgart Administrative Court and the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg. "The state only made specific financial contributions under public subsidy law, as clearly and unambiguously defined in the financing agreement. The Administrative Court of Appeal has now confirmed this in its decision."

The Stuttgart Administrative Court had dismissed Deutsche Bahn's claim for approximately EUR7 billion in additional project costs against the State of Baden-Wurttemberg and other defendants relating to the financing of the Stuttgart 21 project. The decision of the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg, which is final and cannot be appealed, establishes the Stuttgart Administrative Court's ruling as legally binding and definitively establishes that the State of Baden-Wurttemberg is not responsible for covering the significant cost overruns of the Stuttgart 21 project. Neither the so-called 'negotiation clause' in the Stuttgart 21 financing agreement, nor any other contractual or statutory basis, creates an obligation for the state to bear these additional costs in whole or in part

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE PARTNER ON USING LEGAL KNOWLEDGE AS A SPRINGBOARD

In a Q&A with International Financial Law Review as part of its "Five minutes with" series, White & Case partner Jessica Chen discussed her practice and career.

When providing an overview of her work, Jessica explained: "I help companies raise capital, mainly using their equity, in order to fund initiatives that help the company grow." She noted that she spends much of her days working with clients and colleagues across Europe and Asia, also emphasizing the support she receives from the "brilliant associates" she works alongside.

"The most exciting aspect is that each day is different, and I never know what new issues will come my way," Jessica said, adding that the Firm is "at the forefront of structuring new ways of doing things and figuring out how it works."

While Jessica noted the importance of understanding the rules as a lawyer, she argues that "a truly great lawyer then uses that knowledge as a springboard."

The investment will support the company's plans to accelerate global growth, scale operations and expand its commercial reach and product portfolio. As part of the transaction, two members of the Summit Partners team will join the Dreampath DiagnosticsBoard of Directors.

Dreampath Diagnostics is a global leader in digital sample management systems for anatomical pathology laboratories.

The White & Case team which advised on the transaction was led by partner Guillaume Vitrich (Paris) and included partners Alexandre Jaurett, Clara Hainsdorf, Orion Berg, Quirec de Kersauson, Brice Engel, Kami Haeri (all Paris), Hope Anderson (Los Angeles), David Bond, Farhad Jalinous (both Washington, DC), Jaye Kasper, Bethany Hills, Tal Marnin, Sasha Belinkie, Scott Fryman (all New York), Carlos Daroca (Madrid) and Alan Bao (Beijing), counsel Amanda Woodall (Houston), Katrin Helle (Berlin), Annie Anderson, Heidi Schmid (both New York) and Chris Thomas (London) and associates Nicolas Alfonsi, Marco Hladik, Matthieu Shamloo, Sarah Kouchad, Hovig Cancioglu, Olga Kosno, Louis Roussier, Pauline Abbouche, Gregoire Baudry, Clement Bellaclas, Mathilde Bernier, Dylan Deligny (all Paris), Benedict Tansey, Kyle Spencer, Alec Buchanan, Amanda Kingsley, Sam Ahmad (all London), Edward Ernst (New York), Allison Kepkay, Timothy Sensenig (both Washington, DC), Lucee Laursen (Chicago), Zixie Zhu (Beijing), Qianru Hong (Shanghai) and Joao Lacerda (London & Brussels).

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES FOTOWATIO RENEWABLE VENTURES (FRV) AUSTRALIA ON DEVELOPMENT AND FINANCING OF GNARWARRE BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM

Global law firm White & Case LLP has advised Fotowatio Renewable Ventures (FRV) Australia on the development and financing of the 250 MW/500 MWh Gnarwarre battery energy storage system (BESS), near Geelong in the state of Victoria.

"FRVAustralia successfully leveraged its existing portfolio financing facility to finance the construction of the Gnarwarre BESS," said White & Case partner Candice Ota, who co-led the Firm's deal team. "Portfolio financing facilities can provide developers with greater flexibility to fund their development pipeline."

The stand-alone BESS project includes grid forming inverters and will assist the national electrical network to compensate for times of peak demand and energy oversupply.

The Gnarwarre BESS is FRVAustralia's largest battery to date and was financed under its A$1.2 billion portfolio financing facility, which was established in July 2024. The loan facility was provided by a syndicate of five financial institutions: Westpac Banking Corporation, United Overseas Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo, KfW IPEX-Bank and Export Development Canada. The project's funding also includes grant funding from the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA), which awarded a A$15 million grant under its Large Scale Battery Storage Funding Round.

Source: Company Website

+ CAHILL SECURES VICTORY FOR GLOBAL SOCIAL MEDIA COMPANY, OVERTURNING CALIFORNIA'S ANTI-DEEPFAKE LAW

Cahill prevailed in a precedent-setting victory for a leading social media platform in the Eastern District of California, where the court struck down a California law that would have forced covered social media platforms to remove or label certain political speech about elections that the State deems false or misleading.

Source: Company Website

+ CAHILL GORDON & REINDEL LLP: CAHILL HONORED WITH SANCTUARY FOR FAMILIES' 2025 ABOVE & BEYOND PRO BONO ACHIEVEMENT AWARD

Cahill has been named a recipient of Sanctuary For Families' 2025 Above & Beyond Pro Bono Achievement Award.

Following years of continual work, a Cahill pro bono team led by partner Joel Kurtzberg and including associates Joe Adams, Lisa Cole, Brigid O'Keefe, Chana Tauber, and Jessica Urgo will receive the Above & Beyond award from Sanctuary For Families in recognition of their representation of a woman seeking custody of her nephew after the sudden death of child's mother and obtaining an order of protection against the child's father, in addition to Cahill's representation in a related Hague Convention case.

When Cahill joined the matter, the Hague court had already issued orders on two separate occasions requiring the child to go back to his father in Italy, despite crediting allegations of abuse. Cahill worked together with another law firm in the Hague case and prevailed in persuading the Hague judge to reverse her prior rulings and keep the child in New York while custody was being litigated because of the grave risk of harm to the child if he were returned to the father in Italy. Cahill also was successful in negotiating a settlement in a Family Court case that provided full legal and physical custody for our client, a 2-year order of protection, and supervised virtual visitation for the father.

DASHBOARD: WHITE & CASE LLP

PermID4296278714Websitehttp://www.whitecase.com/IndustryLaw PracticeAddress75 State Street Boston, Massachusetts 02109-1814 United States

ACTIVITIES:

White & Case LLP, founded in 1901, is a global law firm headquartered in New York City. With over 2,600 lawyers across 44 offices, it serves clients in finance, energy, and technology, specializing in M&A, project finance, and international arbitration. Generating over $2.5 billion annually, White & Case advised on major 2024 deals, including cross-border energy transactions. Its culture fosters collaboration, diversity, and pro bono work, earning high workplace rankings. Competing with Latham & Watkins, White & Case stands out for its global reach and expertise in emerging markets. Recent initiatives include expanding ESG and digital asset practices, aligning with regulatory and tech trends.

+ WHITE & CASE LLP [6 Press Releases]

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES ON LANDMARK ACWA POWER COMPANY RIGHTS ISSUE

Global law firmWhite & Case LLP has advised the underwriters on ACWA Power Company's SAR 7.125 billion rights issue - one of the largest capital raises in the history of the Saudi capital market.

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES WHITEFIBER ON UPSIZED IPO

Global law firmWhite & Case LLP has advised leading artificial intelligence infrastructure solutions provider, WhiteFiber, Inc., on its upsized initial public offering of 9.375 million ordinary shares at a price of US$17.00 per share, including granting the underwriters a 30-day option to purchase up to an additional 1,406,250 ordinary shares at the initial public offering price. WhiteFiber is listed on the Nasdaq Capital Market under the symbol WYFI. The offering closed on August 8, 2025.

WhiteFiber owns high-performance computing data centers and provides cloud services to customers. Its vertically integrated model combines specialized colocation, hosting and cloud services engineered to maximize performance, efficiency and margin for generative AI workloads.

The White & Case team was led by Capital Markets partner Laura Katherine Mann (Houston), and included M&A partners Prat Vallabhaneni, Erica Hogan and Nicholas Luciano (all in New York); Tax partner Neil Clausen (Houston); and Capital Markets associates Melissa Curvino (New York), Bryson Manning, Chanel Holmes, Brandon Wong and Daniel Quesenberry (all in Houston).

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE PARTNER ON USING LEGAL KNOWLEDGE AS A SPRINGBOARD

In a Q&A with International Financial Law Review as part of its "Five minutes with" series, White & Case partner Jessica Chen discussed her practice and career.

When providing an overview of her work, Jessica explained: "I help companies raise capital, mainly using their equity, in order to fund initiatives that help the company grow." She noted that she spends much of her days working with clients and colleagues across Europe and Asia, also emphasizing the support she receives from the "brilliant associates" she works alongside.

"The most exciting aspect is that each day is different, and I never know what new issues will come my way," Jessica said, adding that the Firm is "at the forefront of structuring new ways of doing things and figuring out how it works."

While Jessica noted the importance of understanding the rules as a lawyer, she argues that "a truly great lawyer then uses that knowledge as a springboard."

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES FOTOWATIO RENEWABLE VENTURES (FRV) AUSTRALIA ON DEVELOPMENT AND FINANCING OF GNARWARRE BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM

Global law firmWhite & Case LLP has advised Fotowatio Renewable Ventures (FRV) Australia on the development and financing of the 250 MW/500 MWh Gnarwarre battery energy storage system (BESS), near Geelong in the state of Victoria.

"FRVAustralia successfully leveraged its existing portfolio financing facility to finance the construction of the Gnarwarre BESS," said White & Case partner Candice Ota, who co-led the Firm's deal team. "Portfolio financing facilities can provide developers with greater flexibility to fund their development pipeline."

The stand-alone BESS project includes grid forming inverters and will assist the national electrical network to compensate for times of peak demand and energy oversupply.

The Gnarwarre BESS is FRVAustralia's largest battery to date and was financed under its A$1.2 billion portfolio financing facility, which was established in July 2024. The loan facility was provided by a syndicate of five financial institutions: Westpac Banking Corporation, United Overseas Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo, KfW IPEX-Bank and Export Development Canada. The project's funding also includes grant funding from the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA), which awarded a A$15 million grant under its Large Scale Battery Storage Funding Round.

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE SECURES DISMISSAL OF DEUTSCHE BAHN'S STUTTGART 21 COST OVERRUN LAWSUIT FOR STATE OF BADEN-W RTTEMBERG

Global law firmWhite & Case LLP has secured a victory for the State of Baden-Wurttemberg in the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg, which rejected Deutsche Bahn's request to appeal a 2024 judgment by the Stuttgart Administrative Court related to the financing of the Stuttgart 21 project.

"At no point did the State of Baden-Wurttemberg assume any obligation to cover the cost overruns of the Stuttgart 21 project," said White & Case partner Henning Berger, who led the team which achieved the dismissals before both the Stuttgart Administrative Court and the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg. "The state only made specific financial contributions under public subsidy law, as clearly and unambiguously defined in the financing agreement. The Administrative Court of Appeal has now confirmed this in its decision."

The Stuttgart Administrative Court had dismissed Deutsche Bahn's claim for approximately EUR7 billion in additional project costs against the State of Baden-Wurttemberg and other defendants relating to the financing of the Stuttgart 21 project. The decision of the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg, which is final and cannot be appealed, establishes the Stuttgart Administrative Court's ruling as legally binding and definitively establishes that the State of Baden-Wurttemberg is not responsible for covering the significant cost overruns of the Stuttgart 21 project. Neither the so-called 'negotiation clause' in the Stuttgart 21 financing agreement, nor any other contractual or statutory basis, creates an obligation for the state to bear these additional costs in whole or in part

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES SUMMIT PARTNERS ON INVESTMENT IN DREAMPATH DIAGNOSTICS

Global law firmWhite & Case LLP has advised leading growth-focused investment firm Summit Partners on its investment in Dreampath Diagnostics.

The investment will support the company's plans to accelerate global growth, scale operations and expand its commercial reach and product portfolio. As part of the transaction, two members of the Summit Partners team will join the Dreampath DiagnosticsBoard of Directors.

Dreampath Diagnostics is a global leader in digital sample management systems for anatomical pathology laboratories.

The White & Case team which advised on the transaction was led by partner Guillaume Vitrich (Paris) and included partners Alexandre Jaurett, Clara Hainsdorf, Orion Berg, Quirec de Kersauson, Brice Engel, Kami Haeri (all Paris), Hope Anderson (Los Angeles), David Bond, Farhad Jalinous (both Washington, DC), Jaye Kasper, Bethany Hills, Tal Marnin, Sasha Belinkie, Scott Fryman (all New York), Carlos Daroca (Madrid) and Alan Bao (Beijing), counsel Amanda Woodall (Houston), Katrin Helle (Berlin), Annie Anderson, Heidi Schmid (both New York) and Chris Thomas (London) and associates Nicolas Alfonsi, Marco Hladik, Matthieu Shamloo, Sarah Kouchad, Hovig Cancioglu, Olga Kosno, Louis Roussier, Pauline Abbouche, Gregoire Baudry, Clement Bellaclas, Mathilde Bernier, Dylan Deligny (all Paris), Benedict Tansey, Kyle Spencer, Alec Buchanan, Amanda Kingsley, Sam Ahmad (all London), Edward Ernst (New York), Allison Kepkay, Timothy Sensenig (both Washington, DC), Lucee Laursen (Chicago), Zixie Zhu (Beijing), Qianru Hong (Shanghai) and Joao Lacerda (London & Brussels).

+ BAKER MCKENZIE PUBLISHES ANNUAL SUSTAINABILITY REPORT 2025

Leading global law firm Baker McKenzie has published its Annual Sustainability Report 2025, which provides an overview of the progress the Firm made in 2024 to advance its eight prioritized Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and its broader sustainability strategy.

The report highlights Baker McKenzie's 2024 actions across key sustainability areas - spanning inclusion, diversity and equity, environmental impact, governance and the rule of law, and also reaffirms the Firm's commitment as a longstanding active participant of the UN Global Compact, upholding its Ten Principles on human rights, labor, the environment, and anti-corruption - and more broadly, its dedication to responsible business practices.

2024 was also the year of Baker McKenzie's 75th anniversary, and the Firm celebrated this milestone by demonstrating its deep commitment to local communities through a "Make a Difference Month" in July 2024.

Morgan, Morgan Stanley and Scotiabank, as joint bookrunners, in connection with an approximately USD 450 million initial public offering by Fibra Next. When the 1.4GW project, which is located off the Suffolk coast in the UK, comes into operation in Q4 2026, it will deliver enough clean energy to power 1.3 million British homes. In addition, over 2,300 jobs are expected to be created during construction, with 100 long-term roles supported across its lifetime.

Mei is a market leading specialist in credit solutions, with over 20 years' experience in high-end, cross-border finance transactions. + A&O SHEARMAN [3 Press Releases]

+ A&O SHEARMAN MITIGATING THIRD-PARTY PROVIDER CYBERSECURITY RISKS: NAVIGATING THE AUSTRALIAN LEGAL FRAMEWORK

Cybersecurity breaches originating from third-party providers (TPPs) are an escalating concern for Australian businesses. As supply chain risks grow, there is a mounting public expectation that the entity that commissioned the collection of personal information remains accountable for its protection, even when such personal information is handled and managed by a TPP.

Despite recent political commentary in Australia regarding the tightening of privacy laws, there is no current legal requirement for businesses to store data, including any personal information, in-house. As a result, organizations are increasingly relying on TPPs to manage their data as TPPs can be highly cost-effective and often provide superior specialist services. To maximize the benefit of using TPPs, robust legal risk management is essential.

Source: Company Website

+ A&O SHEARMAN UK PENSIONS: WHAT'S NEW THIS WEEKAUGUST 4, 2025

TPR blog post on managing systemic risks The latest blog post from the Pensions Regulator (TPR) highlights the importance of managing systemic risks, including climate change, nature loss and broader ESG factors, as "a core part" of effective scheme governance and trustees' fiduciary responsibilities. TPR encourages schemes to use the Taskforce on Nature-related Financial Disclosures (TNFD) resources to inform their thinking. The blog post includes questions trustees should ask themselves to help assess how well equipped they are in this area. TPR urges trustees to engage with the recent consultation on mandating transition plans and asks for input for its transition planning industry group.

Read the blog post.

Data (Use and Access) Act: commencement regulations Regulations have been made bringing certain parts of the Data (Use and Access) Act 2025 into force with effect from August 20, 2025. Provisions potentially relevant to pension schemes include changes relating to processing of special categories of data and modifications to court procedures dealing with data subject access requests. Regulations setting out further details and bringing other parts of the act into force are awaited.

Read the Data (Use and Access) Act 2025 (Commencement No. 1) Regulations 2025.

Source: Company Website

+ A&O SHEARMAN COMMISSION NOT IMPOSSIBLE: NO BRIBERY OR FIDUCIARY BREACH IN CAR FINANCE COMMISSION CASE

In a significant decision for the car finance industry, the UK Supreme Court has decided that lenders who financed car loans were not liable to their customers for bribery for failing to obtain their informed consent to commission payments made by the lenders to the dealers arranging the finance.

The court determined that, for the tort of bribery to be committed, the recipient of the bribe must be a fiduciary, and the dealers did not owe a fiduciary duty to their customers. For the same reason, the lenders had not dishonestly assisted in a breach of fiduciary duty by the dealers.

In relation to one customer, however, liability did arise on the basis there was an unfair relationship between the customer and lender for the purposes of the Consumer Credit Act 1974.

The decision largely overturns the Court of Appeal's controversial judgment from last autumn which held that lenders financing car loans could be liable in such cases.

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES WHITEFIBER ON UPSIZED IPO

Global law firm White & Case LLP has advised leading artificial intelligence infrastructure solutions provider, WhiteFiber, Inc., on its upsized initial public offering of 9.375 million ordinary shares at a price of US$17.00 per share, including granting the underwriters a 30-day option to purchase up to an additional 1,406,250 ordinary shares at the initial public offering price. WhiteFiber is listed on the Nasdaq Capital Market under the symbol WYFI. The offering closed on August 8, 2025.

WhiteFiber owns high-performance computing data centers and provides cloud services to customers. Its vertically integrated model combines specialized colocation, hosting and cloud services engineered to maximize performance, efficiency and margin for generative AI workloads.

The White & Case team was led by Capital Markets partner Laura Katherine Mann (Houston), and included M&A partners Prat Vallabhaneni, Erica Hogan and Nicholas Luciano (all in New York); Tax partner Neil Clausen (Houston); and Capital Markets associates Melissa Curvino (New York), Bryson Manning, Chanel Holmes, Brandon Wong and Daniel Quesenberry (all in Houston).

+ WHITE & CASE SECURES DISMISSAL OF DEUTSCHE BAHN'S STUTTGART 21 COST OVERRUN LAWSUIT FOR STATE OF BADEN-W RTTEMBERG

Global law firm White & Case LLP has secured a victory for the State of Baden-Wurttemberg in the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg, which rejected Deutsche Bahn's request to appeal a 2024 judgment by the Stuttgart Administrative Court related to the financing of the Stuttgart 21 project.

"At no point did the State of Baden-Wurttemberg assume any obligation to cover the cost overruns of the Stuttgart 21 project," said White & Case partner Henning Berger, who led the team which achieved the dismissals before both the Stuttgart Administrative Court and the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg. "The state only made specific financial contributions under public subsidy law, as clearly and unambiguously defined in the financing agreement. The Administrative Court of Appeal has now confirmed this in its decision."

The Stuttgart Administrative Court had dismissed Deutsche Bahn's claim for approximately EUR7 billion in additional project costs against the State of Baden-Wurttemberg and other defendants relating to the financing of the Stuttgart 21 project. The decision of the Administrative Court of Appeal of Baden-Wurttemberg, which is final and cannot be appealed, establishes the Stuttgart Administrative Court's ruling as legally binding and definitively establishes that the State of Baden-Wurttemberg is not responsible for covering the significant cost overruns of the Stuttgart 21 project. Neither the so-called 'negotiation clause' in the Stuttgart 21 financing agreement, nor any other contractual or statutory basis, creates an obligation for the state to bear these additional costs in whole or in part

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE PARTNER ON USING LEGAL KNOWLEDGE AS A SPRINGBOARD

In a Q&A with International Financial Law Review as part of its "Five minutes with" series, White & Case partner Jessica Chen discussed her practice and career.

When providing an overview of her work, Jessica explained: "I help companies raise capital, mainly using their equity, in order to fund initiatives that help the company grow." She noted that she spends much of her days working with clients and colleagues across Europe and Asia, also emphasizing the support she receives from the "brilliant associates" she works alongside.

"The most exciting aspect is that each day is different, and I never know what new issues will come my way," Jessica said, adding that the Firm is "at the forefront of structuring new ways of doing things and figuring out how it works."

While Jessica noted the importance of understanding the rules as a lawyer, she argues that "a truly great lawyer then uses that knowledge as a springboard."

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES SUMMIT PARTNERS ON INVESTMENT IN DREAMPATH DIAGNOSTICS

Global law firm White & Case LLP has advised leading growth-focused investment firm Summit Partners on its investment in Dreampath Diagnostics.

The investment will support the company's plans to accelerate global growth, scale operations and expand its commercial reach and product portfolio. As part of the transaction, two members of the Summit Partners team will join the Dreampath DiagnosticsBoard of Directors.

Dreampath Diagnostics is a global leader in digital sample management systems for anatomical pathology laboratories.

The White & Case team which advised on the transaction was led by partner Guillaume Vitrich (Paris) and included partners Alexandre Jaurett, Clara Hainsdorf, Orion Berg, Quirec de Kersauson, Brice Engel, Kami Haeri (all Paris), Hope Anderson (Los Angeles), David Bond, Farhad Jalinous (both Washington, DC), Jaye Kasper, Bethany Hills, Tal Marnin, Sasha Belinkie, Scott Fryman (all New York), Carlos Daroca (Madrid) and Alan Bao (Beijing), counsel Amanda Woodall (Houston), Katrin Helle (Berlin), Annie Anderson, Heidi Schmid (both New York) and Chris Thomas (London) and associates Nicolas Alfonsi, Marco Hladik, Matthieu Shamloo, Sarah Kouchad, Hovig Cancioglu, Olga Kosno, Louis Roussier, Pauline Abbouche, Gregoire Baudry, Clement Bellaclas, Mathilde Bernier, Dylan Deligny (all Paris), Benedict Tansey, Kyle Spencer, Alec Buchanan, Amanda Kingsley, Sam Ahmad (all London), Edward Ernst (New York), Allison Kepkay, Timothy Sensenig (both Washington, DC), Lucee Laursen (Chicago), Zixie Zhu (Beijing), Qianru Hong (Shanghai) and Joao Lacerda (London & Brussels).

Source: Company Website

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES FOTOWATIO RENEWABLE VENTURES (FRV) AUSTRALIA ON DEVELOPMENT AND FINANCING OF GNARWARRE BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM

Global law firm White & Case LLP has advised Fotowatio Renewable Ventures (FRV) Australia on the development and financing of the 250 MW/500 MWh Gnarwarre battery energy storage system (BESS), near Geelong in the state of Victoria.

"FRVAustralia successfully leveraged its existing portfolio financing facility to finance the construction of the Gnarwarre BESS," said White & Case partner Candice Ota, who co-led the Firm's deal team. "Portfolio financing facilities can provide developers with greater flexibility to fund their development pipeline."

The stand-alone BESS project includes grid forming inverters and will assist the national electrical network to compensate for times of peak demand and energy oversupply.

The Gnarwarre BESS is FRVAustralia's largest battery to date and was financed under its A$1.2 billion portfolio financing facility, which was established in July 2024. The loan facility was provided by a syndicate of five financial institutions: Westpac Banking Corporation, United Overseas Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo, KfW IPEX-Bank and Export Development Canada. The project's funding also includes grant funding from the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA), which awarded a A$15 million grant under its Large Scale Battery Storage Funding Round.

Source: Company Website

+ CAHILL GORDON & REINDEL LLP: CAHILL HONORED WITH SANCTUARY FOR FAMILIES' 2025 ABOVE & BEYOND PRO BONO ACHIEVEMENT AWARD

Cahill has been named a recipient of Sanctuary For Families' 2025 Above & Beyond Pro Bono Achievement Award.

Following years of continual work, a Cahill pro bono team led by partner Joel Kurtzberg and including associates Joe Adams, Lisa Cole, Brigid O'Keefe, Chana Tauber, and Jessica Urgo will receive the Above & Beyond award from Sanctuary For Families in recognition of their representation of a woman seeking custody of her nephew after the sudden death of child's mother and obtaining an order of protection against the child's father, in addition to Cahill's representation in a related Hague Convention case.

When Cahill joined the matter, the Hague court had already issued orders on two separate occasions requiring the child to go back to his father in Italy, despite crediting allegations of abuse. Cahill worked together with another law firm in the Hague case and prevailed in persuading the Hague judge to reverse her prior rulings and keep the child in New York while custody was being litigated because of the grave risk of harm to the child if he were returned to the father in Italy. Cahill also was successful in negotiating a settlement in a Family Court case that provided full legal and physical custody for our client, a 2-year order of protection, and supervised virtual visitation for the father.

ACTIVITIES:

White & Case LLP, founded in 1901, is a global law firm headquartered in New York City. With over 2,600 lawyers across 44 offices, it serves clients in finance, energy, and technology, specializing in M&A, project finance, and international arbitration. Generating over $2.5 billion annually, White & Case advised on major 2024 deals, including cross-border energy transactions. Its culture fosters collaboration, diversity, and pro bono work, earning high workplace rankings. Competing with Latham & Watkins, White & Case stands out for its global reach and expertise in emerging markets. Recent initiatives include expanding ESG and digital asset practices, aligning with regulatory and tech trends.

+ WHITE & CASE ADVISES FOTOWATIO RENEWABLE VENTURES (FRV) AUSTRALIA ON DEVELOPMENT AND FINANCING OF GNARWARRE BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM

Global law firmWhite & Case LLP has advised Fotowatio Renewable Ventures (FRV) Australia on the development and financing of the 250 MW/500 MWh Gnarwarre battery energy storage system (BESS), near Geelong in the state of Victoria.

"FRVAustralia successfully leveraged its existing portfolio financing facility to finance the construction of the Gnarwarre BESS," said White & Case partner Candice Ota, who co-led the Firm's deal team. "Portfolio financing facilities can provide developers with greater flexibility to fund their development pipeline."
